snippet: Pathologists took up the question of what contributed to the death of the Soviet leader Vladimir Ilyich Lenin at the age of 53.
abstract: Neurologist Harry Vinters and Russian historian Lev Lurie present evidence, at clinicopathological conference on historical figures, that fatal stroke suffered by Russian leader Vladimir Lenin in 1924 was caused by poisoning; suggest that the most likely perpetrator of the crime was Joseph Stalin, who saw Lenin as a major political obstacle.
lead_paragraph: Pathologists took up the question of what contributed to the death of the Soviet leader Vladimir Ilyich Lenin at the age of 53.

headline.seo: Lenin’s Death Remains a Mystery for Doctors
headline.main: Lenin’s Stroke: Doctor Has a Theory (and a Suspect)
headline.print_headline: The Death Of Lenin: Tracking A Suspect
